isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - ELECTRONIC CONTROL MODULE (ECM) POWER SUPPLY

para.hotlnk: Figure 3.60 Electronic Control Module Power Supply

figure.caption: Figure 3.60 Electronic Control Module Power Supply

svcsubproc.title: CIRCUIT FUNCTIONS
svcsubproc.para: The ECM receives 12 volt operating power with the key ON from the ECM power relay. The ECM also receives 12 volt battery power at all times for the Keep Alive Memory function.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Switched Power
svcsubproc.para: Turning the key ON energizes the ECM power relay causing 12 volt battery power to be applied to ECM terminals 37 and 57.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Keep Alive Memory Power
svcsubproc.para: Battery power is applied at all times to support the ECMs keep alive memory. Refer to KEEP ALIVE MEMORY POWER CIRCUITS in this section for additional information.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Power Ground
svcsubproc.para: ECM terminals 40 and 60 are grounded through the dash harness to the negative battery terminal.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: The ECM monitors voltage at terminals 37 and 57. If the ECM continuously receives less than 8 volts or more that 15 volts a fault code will be set. The fault codes do not cause the Warning light to be turned ON. If the condition is intermittent, the code will be logged as an inactive code.

para.hotlnk: Figure 3.61 Electronic Control Module Power Supply Diagnostics

figure.caption: Figure 3.61 Electronic Control Module Power Supply Diagnostics

svcsubproc.para: Connector (395) - Check connector (395) with relay removed, ECM connector (379) disconnected
and key ON.

entry.para: < than 10.5 v check connections, 0 v check for open/short to ground or blown fuse
< than 10.5 v check connections, 0 v check for open/short to ground or blown fuse
< than 10.5 v check grd circuit connections, 0 v check for open ground circuit
Any voltage indicates a short to ground in ECM feed circuit

svcsubproc.para: Connector (379) - Check with breakout box installed on engine harness only and connector (395)
with relay removed and key OFF.

entry.para: > 5 ohms indicates open or poor connection in ground circuits.
< 1000 ohms indicates a short to ground

svcsubproc.para: Connector (379) to (395) - Check with breakout box installed on engine harness only and
connector (395) with relay removed and key OFF

entry.para: > 5 ohms indicates an open or poor connection. If <5 ohms the ECM power relay is suspect.
112 = Internal power was more than 18 volts.
113 = Internal power was less than 6.5 volts.
224 = Keep Alive Memory in ECM lost.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to the Electronic Control Module power supply circuit diagram Figure 3.62
for the following discussion.

The Electronic Control Module (ECM) Power Relay (395) has battery power supplied directly from the batteries to terminal 30. This circuit is protected by the 15A ECM PWR fuse that is part of the battery cable assembly.

When the key switch is turned ON, the ECM Power Relay (395) is energized by ignition power from 5A fuse F5 (5A fuse C1 with FBC) at the relay control coil terminal 85. With the ECM Power Relay (395) energized, power flows through the normally open (N.O.) relay contacts (30 to 87) then on circuit 97AR to ECM connector (379), terminals 37 and 57.

The ground side of the ECM Power Relay control coil (terminal 86) is grounded by circuit 11-GK at the Electronic Ground Stud located at the cab. The Diode Assy (415) prevents the electronic components from voltage spikes created by the relay opening and closing.
The ECM power ground terminals 40 and 60 are grounded through ECM connector (379) at the negative battery terminal.

svcsubproc.title: ECM DIAGNOSTICS
svcsubproc.para: If the ECM continuously receives less than 8 volts or more than 15 volts at terminals 37 and 57, it will cause Flash Code 112 or 113 to be set.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 112

para.title: ECM: INTERNAL VOLTAGE POWER OUT OF RANGE HIGH

svcsubproc.para: Code 112 can be caused by either of two conditions:

step1.para: Vehicle voltage supply to the ECM is continuously more than 15 volts. Excessive voltage can be caused by a defective alternator.
The ECM has an internal fault.

svcsubproc.para: If the condition causing code 112 is intermittent, the code will change from active to inactive status. Code 112 does not cause the Engine Warning light to turn ON.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 113

para.title: ECM: INTERNAL VOLTAGE POWER OUT OF RANGE LOW

svcsubproc.para: Code 113 can be caused by consistently less than 8 volts being applied to ECM terminals 37 and 57. This can be caused by a defective alternator, low batteries, and/or increased resistance in the battery feed circuits. Code 113 does not turn the Engine Warning Light ON. If the condition causing Code 113 to set is an intermittent condition, when the condition is no longer present, the code status will change from active to inactive.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 224
svcsubproc.para: Flash code 224 can be caused by high or low battery power supply to ECM terminal 1 OR an internal ECM error.

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: If Flash Code 112 is active, refer to CTS- 5000 Master Service Manual, GROUP 08 - ALTERNATORS and troubleshoot the charging system.

If Flash Code 113 is active or NO voltage is present to the ECM, perform TESTING ECM POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITS Figure 3.63.
If the power supply to the ECM checks good, replace the ECM.
If a vehicle no-start condition is present and there is no power to the ECM (Prolink displays voltage supply to ECM), perform TESTING ECM POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITS Figure 3.63.

svcsubproc.title: Before Performing Any Tests
svcsubproc.para: Inspect ECM power relay circuit connectors for pushed back, damaged, corroded or dirty terminals as well as making sure the terminals and wires are properly crimped. Make sure connectors are properly joined together. Also check for damage to wiring, and clean, tight battery and ground connections.
